title: You Don’t Have to Feel Everything Right Away
body: If your body feels far away, that’s not failure — it’s wisdom. You protected yourself by leaving it once. Coming back doesn’t have to be fast or complete. Just a fingertip. Just a breath.
echo_intro: This is for the ones still learning to be here again.

title: Movement Is Grounding Too
body: Stillness isn’t the only path to calm. Rocking, walking, pacing — these aren’t signs of failure. They’re self-regulating strategies in motion. Let your body lead.
echo_intro: If you feel guilty for needing to move, read this.

title: The Tiny Movements Matter
body: Curl your toes. Unclench your jaw. Stretch your fingers wide. You don’t need a full body reset. Just small reminders that you’re here, now, and still yours.
echo_intro: Try this when you're barely holding your body together.

title: Your Body Isn’t the Enemy
body: If your body feels unsafe, it’s because something once made it that way. You’re not broken. You’re recovering. This body still wants to protect you — even if it forgot how to feel like home.
echo_intro: For those at war with their own skin.

title: Track Sensation, Not Stories
body: Don’t try to name your emotions. Start with your body. Where’s the tightness? The buzz? The cold spot? Sensation leads the way when words get lost.
echo_intro: When the mind is loud but unclear — drop into the body.

title: Breathe From the Middle
body: Place a hand on your belly. Let it rise. Let it fall. Deep breath doesn’t mean dramatic — it means low, slow, and steady. You can breathe without performing calm.
echo_intro: Try this if your chest feels tight but still won’t release.

title: Your Body Remembers in Movements
body: A clenched fist. A hunched shoulder. A curl into stillness. These aren’t random — they’re rituals your body made to survive. You’re not dramatic. You’re remembering.
echo_intro: This is for the one who shrinks without knowing why.

title: Your Body Doesn’t Need to Make Sense
body: Shaking, sweating, avoiding touch — your body’s wisdom might not be logical, but it is real. You don’t have to explain it for it to deserve respect.
echo_intro: When you want to trust your body but don’t understand it.

title: Heavy Can Be Healing
body: Some bodies don’t want lightness. They want weight. A blanket. A hand. A hug that holds. Heaviness isn’t restriction — it’s nervous system clarity.
echo_intro: For the one who calms through compression.

title: Borrow Someone Else’s Calm
body: You don’t have to self-soothe every time. Sometimes the body calms by being near someone else who’s steady. That’s not dependency — that’s nervous system honesty.
echo_intro: For when you need someone’s breath beside yours.

title: You’re Not Disgusting — You’re Disconnected
body: If touching your own skin feels like a punishment — that’s not vanity or weakness. That’s survival grief. You’re not repulsive. You’re hurting. Come back slowly.
echo_intro: This one’s for the mirror you’re avoiding.

title: Touch Doesn’t Have to Mean Intimacy
body: Not all touch needs to mean closeness. It can mean presence. Connection. Regulation. You’re allowed to define what makes contact safe — and start there.
echo_intro: For the one who craves touch but flinches at it too.

title: You’re Not Broken — You’re Signaling
body: A nervous system in pain doesn’t need punishment. It needs listening. If you’re short-fused, slow, or spacing out — that’s not defect. That’s signal.
echo_intro: This is for the one who blames their body for crying out.

title: You’re Allowed to Rest *In* Your Body
body: You don’t have to bypass your body to rest. You can soften into it — even the sore parts. Even the frozen parts. You’re allowed to belong in this skin again.
echo_intro: This one’s for anyone learning how to rest without leaving.

title: Your Movement Isn’t Wrong — It’s Smart
body: Bouncing knees. Tapping fingers. Pacing. These aren’t problems to solve — they’re strategies your nervous system developed to stay functional. You’re not annoying. You’re regulating.
echo_intro: This is for the one who’s been told to sit still for too long.
